update.description:
This PR introduces the following features:

* A new `dock_block` model. This is a static model of the modular floating dock used to build the RobotX docks. It has a simple box as a collision shape. I didn’t add any inertial properties as we’ll create static docks to avoid physics instabilities among all blocks.
* A new `dock_generator.erb` used to generate docks based on a string. As examples, I’ve generated the RobotX 2016 and 2018 docks. I’ll create a tutorial describing how to create a new dock but the process can be summarized as:

    * Create a new directory under `robotx_gazebo/models`with the name of your dock.
    * Create a `model.config`file.
    * Create a `model.sdf.erb` file using the template from `dock_2016/model.sdf.erb` or `dock_2018_model.sdf.erb`.
    * Modify the `laout` variable with the shape that you want to create.
    * Add the name of your new `erb` file to the `robotx_gazebo/CMakeLists.txt`section in which we add the list of model files to be processed by erb.
    

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3052397381-docks.png)
update.title: Dock

content.raw: My idea is to have a few dock block meshes available \(1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4\) and use a variable `block_size` in the `model.sdf.erb` . The generator will take the dimensions of this block into account and choose the right mesh. But for now, I think this is a good enough base line until we get the next round of meshes.
content.html: My idea is to have a few dock block meshes available (1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4) and use a variable block_size in the model.sdf.erb . The generator will take the dimensions of this block into account and choose the right mesh. But for now, I think this is a good enough base line until we get the next round of meshes.

content.raw:
Performance is definitely good with this change! It seems the dimensions of the docks have changed, but as we don’t know the true dimensions this is okay for now. 

‌

If another mesh is being created anyways, perhaps we should consider getting the true dimensions of the docks and getting a single mesh for each of them as they only change potentially every 2 years
content.html:
Performance is definitely good with this change! It seems the dimensions of the docks have changed, but as we don’t know the true dimensions this is okay for now.

‌

If another mesh is being created anyways, perhaps we should consider getting the true dimensions of the docks and getting a single mesh for each of them as they only change potentially every 2 years

update.description:
This PR introduces the following features:

* A new `dock_block` model. This is a static model of the modular floating dock used to build the RobotX docks. It has a simple box as a collision shape. I didn’t add any inertial properties as we’ll create static docks to avoid physics instabilities among all blocks.
* A new `dock_generator.erb` used to generate docks based on a string. As examples, I’ve generated the RobotX 2016 and 2018 docks. I’ll create a tutorial describing how to create a new dock but the process can be summarized as:

    * Create a new directory under `robotx_gazebo/models`with the name of your dock.
    * Create a `model.config`file.
    * Create a `model.sdf.erb` file using the template from `dock_2016/model.sdf.erb` or `dock_2018_model.sdf.erb`.
    * Modify the `laout` variable with the shape that you want to create.
    * Add the name of your new `erb` file to the `robotx_gazebo/CMakeLists.txt`section in which we add the list of model files to be processed by erb.
    

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3052397381-docks.png)
update.title: Dock

content.raw: It seems that the loading issue and the drop in FPS might be caused by the big number of visuals generated \(~300\). As a work-around, the dock\_block has been converted into  the equivalent of a grid of 4x4 blocks. This should speedup things. Note that the mesh hasn’t been updated, it’s just scaled until we have an updated 4x4 mesh. [a6c78cf](#!/osrf/vmrc/commits/a6c78cf273e4ac8a5d942972be9142f0b1a33cc1?at=default)
content.html: It seems that the loading issue and the drop in FPS might be caused by the big number of visuals generated (~300). As a work-around, the dock_block has been converted into the equivalent of a grid of 4x4 blocks. This should speedup things. Note that the mesh hasn’t been updated, it’s just scaled until we have an updated 4x4 mesh. a6c78cf

content.raw:
The models will appear in gazebo as 

    robotx_dock_2016
content.html:
The models will appear in gazebo as 

robotx_dock_2016

content.raw:
Using unique names for each model block seems to fix the issue of not being able to visualize the model in gzclient. [f367a21](#!/osrf/vmrc/commits/f367a218cf1481fab84f1d101b6545d88c31be22?at=default)

The issue with the long time needed to load the dock and the impact in gzclient are still there.
content.html:
Using unique names for each model block seems to fix the issue of not being able to visualize the model in gzclient. f367a21

The issue with the long time needed to load the dock and the impact in gzclient are still there.

content.raw:
The erb generation is sweet!

 Currently, I can’t get this to load on my machine. when I click to insert it, gazebo freezes for 10 seconds or so then just shows one of the blocks. I’m worried that loading in all these blocks will cause serious performance issues. Perhaps a mesh could be generated by erb rather than a gazebo model?

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/4104364637-dockinsert.png)
content.html:
The erb generation is sweet!

Currently, I can’t get this to load on my machine. when I click to insert it, gazebo freezes for 10 seconds or so then just shows one of the blocks. I’m worried that loading in all these blocks will cause serious performance issues. Perhaps a mesh could be generated by erb rather than a gazebo model?

‌
